heading: Views
intro: Views represents the visible part of the application.
description:
A view can be small or big, and it can include other views. The template for a view can be stored in a file (View) or it can be provided as a string in your PHP code (InlineView, StringView and FormatView ).

The syntax for the templates used by View and InlineView is normal HTML and PHP. In general they should have a minimum of PHP code, mostly HTML and placeholders which can be coded as <?=$variable?> provided that short_open_tag is enabled in php.ini or in .htaccess. This is enabled by default in PHP 5.4 and later. For PHP 5.3 with disabled short_open_tag you must use full PHP tags:
<?php echo $variable; ?>

The syntax for StringView is as for PHP double quoted strings, variables are without any tags, just a $ prefix. This class is also for inline short templates and it works regardless of short_open_tag settings.

The FormatView class use even simpler placeholders, it does not support PHP tags or variables, only string format specifiers like %s.

For more information and examples, check the view classes in the menu above.
